Sinking rates are dependent on several factors, including particle excess density and porosity, which vary based on particle origin and type. Additionally, particle characteristics are transformed while sinking. We compare optically-measured particle size spectra profiles (Underwater Vision Profiler 5, UVP) with contemporaneous measurements of particle flux made using sediment traps and 234Th:238U disequilibrium on six process cruises from the California Current Ecosystem (CCE) LTER Program. These measurements allow us to assess the efficacy of size-flux relationships for estimating fluxes from optical particle size measurements. We find that previously published parameterizations that estimate carbon flux from UVP profiles are a poor fit to direct flux measurements in the CCE. This discrepancy is found to result primarily from the important role of fecal pellets in particle flux. These pellets are primarily in a size range (i.e., 100 – 400 µm) that is not well-resolved as images by the UVP due to the resolution of the sensor. We develop new, CCE-optimized parameters for use in an algorithm estimating carbon flux from UVP data in the southern California Current (Flux = ∑_(i=1)^x▒〖n_i A〖d_i〗^B ∆d_i 〗), with A = 15.4, B = 1.05, d = particle diameter (mm) and Flux in units of mg C m-2 d-1. We caution, however, that increased accuracy in flux estimates derived from optical instruments will require devices with greater resolution, the ability to differentiate fecal pellets from low porosity marine snow aggregates, and improved sampling of rapidly sinking fecal pellets. We also find that the particle size-flux relationships may be different within the euphotic zone than in the shallow twilight zone and hypothesize that the changing nature of sinking particles with depth must be considered when investigating the remineralization length scale of sinking particles in the ocean.

DISS_description.DISS_title: A New Value for the Deuteron to Proton Mass Ratio from Precision Measurements of the Cyclotron Frequencies of H2+ and D+

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: This thesis describes the relevant background, process, and results of two measurements of the cyclotron frequency ratio (CFR) of H2+/D+ as measured using a hyperbolic Penning trap, to determine the deuteron-to-proton mass ratio m(d)/m(p). The first of these measurements was done using the ``alternating-technique" in which the H2+ and D+ ions are simultaneously trapped, but measured separately, with the ion being measured centered in the trap as the other ion is held in a 2 mm cyclotron orbit before exchanging the positions of the ions to measure the newly centered ion. This measurement resulted in a value of m(d)/m(p) = 1.999 007 501 274(38), which has an uncertainty three times smaller than the current CODATA value. The second measurement detailed in this thesis attempted to improve upon the precision of the first by performing simultaneous measurements of cyclotron frequency on the H2+ and D+ ions. This method, which was developed at MIT and only used for four ion pairs of m/q ~ 30, had not been used in over a decade, and never for light ions such as H2+ and D+. Using this method we obtained a value of m(d)/m(p) = 1.000 007 501 272(9), reducing our uncertainty by a factor of 4 from our previous measurement.

Cyclotron frequency ratio measurement using H2+ is complicated by the 20 bound vibrational energy states and over 200 metastable rotational energy states which it can be found in. These energy states shift the mass of the H2+ due to the mass energy relation E=mc^2, and must be accounted for in the precision measurement of the CFR. The vibrational energy states could be observed using the alternating measurement technique and clearly identified using the simultaneous measurement technique. This, to our knowledge, is the first demonstration of observation of quantum excitation through direct mass-measurement. Correction was made for rotational quantum energy to the alternating-technique results by the approximation of mass shift through maximum likelihood estimation using a model of rotational excitation. Increased resolution using the simultaneous measurement technique allowed the fitting of specific rotational states to measurements taken, using the minimization of chi-squared when comparing our data to known rovibrational energy levels, drastically reducing the contribution to uncertainty from rotational quantum excitation.

DISS_description.DISS_title: EXPLORING THE MOTIVATION AND EXPERIENCES OF WOMEN IN THE COMPUTER SCIENCE MAJOR AT FLORIDA RESEARCH UNIVERSITY

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: College, Computer science major, High education, Undergraduate, University, Women

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: This study examined the factors contributing to the underrepresentation of women studying undergraduate Computer Science (CS) at Florida Research University (FRU), a preeminent public university. Even as the growing popularity of computing technologies has boosted enrollment numbers in CS majors over the past decade, women’s attrition rate remains much higher than that of their male counterparts (FL DOE, 2021). The research literature on women in science and math majors identifies a number of reasons for this gender gap, including the lack of pre-collegiate exposure, stereotype threats from both society and the classroom, and embedded biases in the curriculum itself (Holmberg-Wright & Wright, 2018; Ellis et al., 2016). To date, there has not been an in-depth look into women’s experiences enrolled in the CS major at FRU, and this research was intended to fill that void.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Autism and the Black & Brown Student College Experience: Enhancing the Narrative

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Black and Brown college students with autism are missing in the higher education research surrounding the college experience and college readiness. This is important because understanding the college experience and college readiness for college students center many debates and research queries within higher education practice and policy (Carnevale et al., 2010; Hurtado et al., 2020). Research also asserts these barriers are further compounded when considering the intersection of disability and minoritized identities (Chiang et al., 2012). The dominate narrative regarding these college barriers for autistic college students is centered around the experience of White college students with autism. This inadvertently pushes the nuanced experiences of Black and Brown students with autism to the margins and assumes homogeneity for the autistic college experience. Critical theories on race, education, and disability, question the notion of a homogenous experience for all college students with autism and call researchers to intentionally interrogate such notions. Therefore, the purpose of this quantitative study was to describe the experiences, and expectations for Black and Brown college students with autism. The findings of this study demonstrate there are differences for Black and Brown students with autism and their White autistic and non-autistic peers for factors of college readiness and the relationship for College Involvement and Degree Aspiration. The results of this study helped to shed a light on the factors that may influence their perceptions of college readiness for Black and Brown College students with autism, and reiterate that the intersection of race and disability needs to be examined. Further this study served as a resistance to the current autism literature that inadvertently conceals Black and Brown experiences.

DISS_description.DISS_title: SEPARATING THE EFFECTS OF DIFFERENT FLUX PINNING DEFECTS ON THE FIELD, ANGULAR, AND TEMPERATURE DEPENDENCE OF JC IN COMMERICAL REBCO COATED CONDUCTORS

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: critical current density, flux pinning, magnet design, REBCO, superconductivity

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: High critical current density (Jc) in MOCVD REBCO coated conductors is accomplished by highly engineered artificial pinning centers (APC) nanostructures that are, however, difficult to control in repetitive long-length production. Adding APC contributes to the crystallographic Jc anisotropy, where Jc varies considerably with the angle (θ) of the applied magnetic field to the tape-plane. These strong correlated APC result in additional point pins around the nano-columns that provide extra, uncorrelated pinning below 45 K, further complicating the pinning landscape. For accurate magnet quench modeling, wide-ranging Jc(B,T,θ) data is needed, where 72-108° is typical of the important angular range for solenoids (θ=90° when B||tape plane). Here we report on four tapes purchased to the same advanced vortex pinning specification that showed substantial variation in the low T, high B current density for BꞱtape (0) and 108° which correlate well with the varying APC size, volume fraction and density. Jc(B,T, 108°) measurements, ranging from 1 T < B < 15 T at 4.2 K < T < 77 K, were probed using a Ginzburg-Landau model of vortex pinning. To further understand the detailed correlation of nanostructure to Jc, the four tapes underwent detailed Jc(B,T,θ) measurements using a novel torque magnetometer at fields up to 30 T, temperatures from 4.2 K < T < 45 K, and angles from 30°-150°. Tapes with higher densities of long, thin nanorods showed a wider ab-plane peak, while the tape with a low density of thick, short nanorods had a sharp, narrow peak. The tape with the lowest Jc for BꞱtape and a low nanorod density however had the highest Jc(B||ab) at all measured B and T. In summary, we find that substantial variations of the Jc magnitude exist for these 4 representative samples and that the common optimization of tape behavior for BꞱtape is not optimum for angles closer to the ab-planes where many important magnet properties are determined.

DISS_description.DISS_title: The Best There Ever Was, The Best There Ever Will Be: Michael Jordan, LeBron James, Kobe Bryant, Candace Parker, and Performances of Surrogation in Basketball

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: basketball, performance, sports, theatre

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: The Best There Ever Was, The Best There Ever Will Be operates at the intersections of sports and performance studies. This dissertation builds upon Joseph Roach’s concept of surrogation, first outlined in 1996’s Cities of the Dead, with a primary focus on the performances of four specific players in the sport of basketball: Michael Jordan, LeBron James, Kobe Bryant, and Candace Parker. I argue that each performs Roach’s surrogation through media, race, and gender. I also examine the history of women’s basketball, arguing that basketball is an inherently gendered sport in both its origins and practices over the course of its evolution in more than a century. The Best There Ever Was, The Best There Ever Will Be uses performance theory, critical race theory, and gender studies to examine how basketball has become a unique performance tradition. First, I analyze a process called mediatization, arguing that Jordan, James, and Bryant’s performances of mediatization shape how we think of them in basketball culture. I then examine Jordan’s performance as “The Man” of his team and the NBA, using Black masculinity and performativity to create a specific basketball masculinity which James and Bryant surrogate in their own ways. In the third chapter, I pivot to Candace Parker and the WNBA, tracing the history of women’s basketball to argue that basketball itself is an inherently gendered sport through both language and the body. I conclude the project by offering up theoretical concepts of possibility and potentiality, drawing these terms from Daniel Sack’s After Live to argue that they can help us think deeper about surrogation and basketball. Surrogation is key to analyzing the sport of basketball because basketball itself is its own performance practice, one that will be passed down and endure for future generations.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Microwave Spectroscopy of Semiconductor Hosted Two-Dimensional Electron Systems

DISS_abstract.DISS_para:
This dissertation explores several aspects of microwave spectroscopy of two-dimensional electron systems (2DES), motivated by the microwave signatures of Wigner crystal phases that can exist in these systems. The spectroscopy is carried out by means of coplanar waveguide transmission lines patterned onto the top of semiconductor samples.
Wigner crystals form from otherwise mobile charge carriers when inter-carrier Coulomb repulsion overwhelms the kinetic energy. This occurs when the 2DES is sufficiently dilute, for low temperature and small disorder. These solids are insulating due to pinning by disorder, and in the rf or microwave range exhibit ``pinning'' modes, in which pieces of the crystal oscillate within the disorder potential. In high magnetic fields these pinning modes are known to be sharp and can vary widely in frequency. I describe high magnetic field measurements of a series of nominally identical devices with unprecedented low disorder and which only vary in the thickness of the quantum well that house the 2DES. This research has demonstrated the lowest frequency pinning mode observed to date, and further shows that the pinning is due to alloy disorder in the confining barriers that form the quantum well. A self consistent model of the wave functions of the quantum wells gives a good explanation of the pinning frequency as a function of well thickness.
Wigner crystals are predicted to form in zero magnetic field as well, although at much lower carrier densities, and should have microwave signatures. An excellent candidate for housing such a solid is AlAs. In exploring 2DES in AlAs to search for microwave signatures of Wigner crystallization at zero magnetic field, we found a novel type of cyclotron resonance, in which plasma shift due to finite sample size is absent
In another step toward studying 2DES at extremely low carrier density I developed a new type of transmission line, a coplanar waveguide whose slots are filled with resistive film, a resistively loaded coplanar waveguide (RLCPW), to measure 2DES. The RLCPW applied to the sample hosting the 2DES provides a uniform metallic surface serving as a gate, to control the areal density of the 2DES. As a demonstration of this technique I present measurements on a Si metal oxide field effect transistors (MOSFET) showing that the RLCPW can be used for quantitative measurements of 2DES microwave conductivity, and additionally measured a heterojunction insulated gate field effect transistor (HIGFET), a type of device that is particularly promising for study of zero magnetic field Wigner crystals.

DISS_description.DISS_title: An Exploration of Black Male Teachers and their Career Decisions in the K-12 Public School System

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Black male teachers, career decisions

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: This study builds on prior literature that examines the importance of Black male teachers in the K-12 public education system. I began by exploring the differential attitudes of Black male teachers and the systemic, institutional, and organizational factors that contribute to their growth or stagnation within the profession. Through the lens of critical race theory, I conducted a narrative inquiry to discover Black male teachers’ experiences in one school district. In an effort to bring attention to the factors, be they support systems or barriers, I acquired an understanding on what they see as critical in shaping their decision to stay in K-12 public education. I explored the extent to which the perceived notions of Black male teachers’ workplace experiences differ from their actual narratives. Findings indicated there is a lack of supports specific to the needs of in place for Black male teachers in place to aid them in their career as teachers. Implications for future research is presented at the conclusion of the study.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Selling Icarus' Wings: A Political Economic Exploration of Red Bull's 'Wings'

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: academic sponsorship, action sports, critical political economy, Red Bull, sponsored media, sponsored research

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: With the use of sponsorship, the company was especially successful in establishing itself as a sports media brand, primarily within action sports industries. However, in addition to sponsoring entertainment media, Red Bull also financially supported scientific research. Thus, despite the intensified public scrutiny placed on the health risks of energy drinks, the company’s involvement in funding academic work allowed it to indirectly participate in relevant scientific discourse or policy debates concerning the regulation of energy beverages. When using a critical political economic lens, both the work of sponsored athletes and sponsored scientists can be understood as similar types of corporate public relations work and subjected to similar pressures of commercialization. Given the complex power dynamics at play within sponsorship agreements, critical political economy’s emphasis on re-emphasizing the undermining of labor evaluation within cultural work is a fruitful foundation for revealing the ways in which corporate sponsors such as Red Bull have used such agreements to sway the creative efforts of athletic performers and university professionals toward their own interests.The results of this analysis reveal that Red Bull actively facilitates the creation of neoliberal discourse through its sponsorship of action sports media and contrarian academic research. As illustrated by the answers to RQ1 and RQ2, the company has extensively invested organizational resources toward developing sponsorship networks within both action sports and nutrition science. Regarding the company’s sponsorship of action sports, at the time of this study, nearly 90% of sponsored athletes listed on Red Bull’s official U.S. website compete in non-traditional sport disciplines. Within research related to energy drinks, the results of this dissertation revealed the company is heavily involved within academic discourse. Out of the 112 studies examined, 27 (or 24%) featured authors with disclosed associations with Red Bull. Not only did this make the organization the most prolific sponsor of energy drink-related research, but out of the 27 studies, 25 exclusively focused on topics disputing scientific evidence indicating potential health risks linked to the use of energy drinks. When contextually examining the political economic dynamics of company’s athletic and academic sponsorship networks, the results to RQ3 highlight Red Bull’s organizational emphasis on unlimited growth is all-encompassing, including not just athletic performance, but all human potential in general.

DISS_description.DISS_title: THE RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN EXECUTIVE FUNCTIONING AND ADAPTIVE SKILLS ACROSS AUTISM SPECTRUM DISORDER BEHAVIORS

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: People with autism spectrum disorder (ASD) consistently have deficits in performing adaptive behaviors (Kenworthy et al., 2010; Perry et al., 2009; Pugliese et al., 2017), which are skills needed to care for oneself, have social interactions, and to function at home, in school, at work, or in the community (Harrison & Oakland, 2015), and may be linked with deficits in executive functioning. Across the United States, diagnoses of ASD continue to increase (Baio et al., 2014; Kogan et al., 2018), suggesting that more children and adolescents with ASD enter adulthood with deficits in adaptive skills (Kanne et al., 2011). Along with deficits in adaptive skills, those with ASD also display deficits in executive functioning (Lind & Williams, 2013), suggesting a possible link between executive functioning and adaptive skills in those with ASD. Executive functioning is the ability to incorporate goal-directed behavior overriding automatic processes for desired processes (Garon et al., 2008). To examine the relationship between these three constructs, the following research questions were asked: 1) What is the association between ASD behaviors and adaptive skills? 2) What is the association between ASD behaviors and executive functioning? 3) Do executive functions moderate the relationship between ASD behaviors and adaptive skills? 4) Does the cognitive triad of executive functioning (inhibition, cognitive flexibility, working memory) moderate the relationship between ASD behaviors and adaptive skills?. The current study included 79 participants (M = 9.92 years; Females = 29%). The results indicated that ASD behaviors have a significant negative relationship with adaptive skills and executive functioning. The findings suggest that executive functioning moderates the association between adaptive skills and ASD behaviors. Because executive functioning is malleable and an area of intervention (Kenworthy et al., 2014; Sasser et al., 2017), these findings are important because they indicate that executive functioning is an area to intervene and improve skills.

DISS_description.DISS_title: CONVERSATIONS, PROGRESSIONS, AND PERCEPTIONS: EXAMINING THE STUDENT EXPERIENCE OF A BLENDED SEL PROGRAM IN HIGH SCHOOLS

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: ABSTRACT Social-Emotional Learning (SEL), the process of developing and utilizing interpersonal skills for everyday life, has become a primary vehicle for structuring students’ social and emotional health in the United States and across the world. In the midst of the COVID-19 pandemic, the importance of understanding SEL practices, is increasingly at the forefront of many discussions in education today. Since “non-academic factors” like SEL were added to U.S. education law (ESSA, 2015), the state of Florida has also added two mandates concerning SEL (Florida Senate Bill 7026: The Marjorie Stoneman Douglas Act and FS 1003.42; Rule 6A-1.094121: Curriculum mandate for four hours of SEL as part of mental health education). This has led to the adoption of SEL programming in schools. In 2018, Martin County Public Schools adopted the BASE Education learning program, an SEL approach that aimed to help high school students, identified as at-risk after a discipline infraction, to “learn about and apply psycho-social concepts through supportive, therapeutic dialogue” (MCSD Code of Conduct, Chapter V, 2022, p.18). BASE Education is an online program currently being implemented in all high schools within the Martin County School District. In purchasing BASE for implementation into the disciplinary process and SEL supports, the district projected that BASE Education would increase self-awareness and increase responsible decision making, thus decreasing discipline referrals. This study examines two components of the disciplinary experience of MCSD students: (1) The SEL experience of high school students referred to BASE Education intervention programming in the Martin County School District, and (2) How students who have participated in [personalized] BASE Education modules describe the nature of their pathway within the online experience. This study represents the first time that an analysis of the student referral experience data and online SEL intervention experiential pathway program data has been undertaken in Martin County Public Schools. Key Words: BASE Education, CASEL, SEL, Social Emotional Learning, SEL Blended Learning, SEL competencies, Responsible-decision making, self-awareness, social-awareness.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Characterization of Emerging Contaminants from Weathered Fossil Fuel-derived Materials as Revealed by Fourier Transform Ion Cyclotron Resonance Mass Spectrometry (FT-ICR MS)

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Emerging contaminants, Fossil fuels, FT-ICR MS, Mass spectrometry, Photooxidation, Road paving materials

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Fossil fuel-derived materials are readily incorporated into the built environment without much knowledge about how they can impact the long-term well-being of natural ecosystems and public health. Ultrahigh resolution Fourier transform ion cyclotron resonance mass spectrometry (FT-ICR MS) has allowed for the molecular characterization of complex fossil fuel-derived materials, such as crude oil and asphalt binder, and their photoproducts that are produced as a result of exposure to weathering processes (i.e. solar irradiation). Photooxidation from sunlight has been identified as the primary phototransformation process responsible for the transformation of fossil fuel-derived materials in the environment. As photooxidation affects these materials, the generation of newly formed oil- and water-soluble compounds becomes a concern and new evidence points to the consideration of these materials as emerging environmental contaminants. Thus, it is important that knowledge regarding the molecular composition, structure, and subsequent behavior of fossil fuel-based photoproducts is acquired as it is valuable in understanding the long-term effects that occur from the use of materials such as crude oil, asphalt binder, and pavement sealant. Specifically, much remains unknown regarding the toxicity of water-soluble photoproducts from fossil fuel-derived materials that can contaminate waterways after introduction to the environment. It is essential that the effects of these potentially toxic compounds in the built environment are understood to combat their effects on the ecosystem, wildlife, and human health.Chapter 1 provides an introductory overview on FT-ICR MS and how it has been used to provide relatively comprehensive molecular profiles for complex unweathered and weathered petroleum-derived materials. Chapter 2 describes the work done to characterize photochemically produced asphaltenes (PPA), a newly formed oil-soluble fraction of crude oil. PPA are of interest as they can persist in the environment due to their inability to degrade over time. Chapter 3 explores an emerging contaminant of great concern, coal tar pavement sealant. This work seeks to provide a relatively comprehensive understanding of petroleum-derived and coal tar-derived sealants and compares how they are transformed after photooxidation which includes molecular characterization, dissolved organic carbon production, and toxicity analysis. Chapter 4 continues to explore coal tar pavement sealant and compares it to another road paving material, asphalt binder. This work focuses on the solubility fractions, maltenes and asphaltenes, from asphalt binder and coal tar sealant and determines their contributions to the production of water-soluble photoproducts. Lastly, Chapter 5 focuses on the potentially harmful water-soluble photoproducts generated from asphalt binder and coal tar sealant that are introduced in Chapters 3 and 4 and seeks to determine their structural profiles by MS/MS techniques. This work also proposes and discusses photochemical pathways that result in the production of different types of water-soluble compounds. This work is of great importance since structural motifs contained in water-soluble photoproducts from fossil-fuel derived materials have yet to be explored. Collectively, this work aims to demonstrate the consideration of fossil fuel-derived oil- and water-soluble photoproducts as emerging environmental contaminants due to their molecular and structural compositions.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Using Subject Level Covariate Information in Bayesian Mixture Models for Basket Trials

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: A basket trial evaluates one or more treatments for efficacy among more than one cancer type in a single clinical trial. Although the treatment targets the common genetic aberration that is associated with different cancer types, the possible heterogeneity in the treatment effects poses challenges in modeling. Compared to traditional designs, basket trials can reduce the time required for testing and, by pooling across cancer types, they also allow the drugs to be tested for rare cancers. Basket trials are gaining increasing importance with advancements in precision medicine. Using covariate information has shown merit for improving efficacy of these trials. We incorporate subject-level biomarker information to aid identification of responsive and non-responsive baskets. We model subjects’ responses using a two-component Bayesian mixture model where the mixture weights depend on a measure of similarly among subjects’ biomarker values. We demonstrate the performance of this model using simulation. We also illustrate a two stage implementation of the model and discuss the application in case of multiple covariates.

DISS_description.DISS_title: An Investigation into Frontal Air-Sea Interaction Processes Associated with the Kuroshio Large Meander

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Unlike other Western Boundary Currents (WBCs), the Kuroshio Current, experiences bimodal path flux variations known as the Kuroshio Large Meander (LM) on the southeastern coast of Japan. In this manuscript, the extent to which the Kuroshio LM on the southeastern coast of Japan can be identified through sea surface temperature (SST) spatial patterns is investigated. The methodology in this manuscript varies from previous work which identified the Kuroshio LM through sea surface height (SSH) data. While SSH data is not found in atmospheric datasets, SST data is often available in atmospheric reanalysis datasets allowing for consistent investigation of ocean-atmosphere interactions using a single dataset. The SST LM index developed in this study is valid in wintertime months, with the highest correlation found in February. The index developed in this study used to investigate both the time-mean near surface wind divergence/convergence (NSWD/NSWC) and precipitation rates within this region. Further criteria explored includes identifying changes in these variables while atmospheric fronts are present in the Kuroshio LM region and is shown that the presence (or absence) of the Kuroshio LM on the southeast coast of Japan has noticeable influence on the impacts related to frontal boundaries, allowing the small-scale SST-induced diabatic signal to be analyzed. The results of this study aid in explaining the time-mean NSWC of atmospheric fronts over this region, except for a small area off Japan, which is shown to have heightened and intensified time-mean non-frontal NSWC and moderate precipitation rates during the Kuroshio LM on the southeastern coast of Japan, which was previously poorly understood.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Teacher Perception on the Use of Game-Based Learning in the Title 1 ELA Curriculum

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: ELA, Elementary School, Game-Based Learning, Teacher Perception, Title 1 Schools

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Teacher perception has been demonstrated to be a key contributor to instructional practices within the classroom. As additional technologies become available to enhance and supplement instructional practices, game-based learning has emerged as an included component to classroom strategies for improved student achievement. With primary focus within the educational field placed on decreasing the achievement gap, emphasis on approaches that demonstrate affective ways of promoting the achievement of minority students has increased over the past few decades. Primary measurements of student achievement begin in 3rd grade. The purpose of this study was to identify and evaluate teacher perceptions on the use of game-based learning software within the contemporary classroom, specifically in the 3rd and 4th grade ELA domain. Survey responses from 823 3rd and 4th grade ELA teachers provided insight to factors contributing to teacher perception on the implementation of game-based learning into the ELA curriculum. In addition to the quantitative survey results, 37 face-to-face interviews were conducted to elicit qualitative information on the factors influencing teacher perception. Analysis of the results indicated that teachers have a generally positive view of the incorporation of GBL into the ELA curriculum. One of the key factors contributing to GBL implementation is an increased level of student engagement. Prior experience with GBL implementation also served as a primary element impacting teacher perception.

DISS_description.DISS_title: THE RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN RISK-TAKING BEHAVIORS AND MEANING IN LIFE

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: This dissertation study sought to examine the relationship between risk-taking behaviors and meaning in life. A United States sample of adults ranging from 18-40 were surveyed via Amazon’s Mechanical Turk platform. Statistical analyses of the relationships between meaning in life group and risk-taking behaviors were assessed using a multivariate analysis of covariance, while treating age as a covariate. Additional statistical analyses of the predictive relationships between variables were assessed through five hierarchical regression models. Results of the study indicated that there were significant group differences for risk-taking behaviors based on meaning in life group. Further examination indicated that there were significant group differences for ethical, financial, and social risk-taking behaviors. Consistent with previous research in risk-taking behaviors and meaning in life, the results also suggest that meaning in life does have a significant predictive relationship with risk-taking behaviors. This study highlights the importance of assessing meaning in life and continuing to expand on the interrelation between presence of meaning and search for meaning on current behavioral functioning. Given that risk-taking behaviors could have negative effects on the individual displaying the behavior, elevate the risk for maladaptive behaviors later in life, and puts others at risk, it becomes apparent that risk-taking behaviors could have lasting negative consequences. Therefore, meaning in life has been identified as a potential protective factor to assess in future research and clinical settings when considering risk-taking motivation or interventions.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Power-signal integrated gate driver design and protection for medium-voltage SiC MOSFETs

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: common-mode transient immunity, DESAT fault protection, Gate driver, high-voltage insulation, medium-voltage SiC MOSFETs, power-signal integrated transmission

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: The newly emerged medium-voltage (MV) silicon carbide (SiC) MOSFETs, spanning 2.5 kV to 15 kV range, are under the rapid developments and have received increasing attention recently. Compared to Si devices, SiC MOSFETs have significant improvements on the blocking voltage, specific on-resistance, switching speed and operating temperature. Therefore, MV SiC MOSFETs have a great potential to improve the efficiency and power density of MV converters, and meanwhile to drive down the system complexity.

As the interface between MV SiC MOSFETs and control circuits, gate driver (GD) performance is critical to fully leverage the potential benefits of SiC devices as well as to enhance the reliability, such as the sufficient common-mode (CM) transient immunity (CMTI) and fast fault protection. Since there is little commercial GDs for MV SiC MOFETs, the research on MV GDs is still being explored, mainly focusing on the isolated GD power supply (GDPS) and fault protection designs. Existing MV GD solutions exhibit bulky size and high cost, since they not only require bulky GDPS to transmit GD power, but also need costly fiber optics (FOs) to transmit gate/ fault signals. State-of-the-art (SOA) GDPSs have demonstrated a reduced size aiming at the MV insulation requirement, but the total GD volume is still comparable or larger than the MV SiC devices.

This dissertation proposes the power-signal integrated GD for MV SiC MOSFETs to minimize the GD footprint, which helps to integrate the GD into MV SiC device packages. This concept is utilized to firstly propose a 20-MHz dual-transformer-based isolated GD with power-signal integrated transmission. It not only removes costly FOs and bulky GDPSs, but also achieves the good timing performance including the full PWM duty-cycle range operation, low propagation delay time, and high PWM duty-cycle resolution. The solid-dielectrics-based insulation scheme is applied for proposed GD, which enables an insulating voltage > 10 kV rms for MV requirements as well as a moderate coupling capacitance to enhance the CMTI. The experimental results have verified the validity of proposed 20-MHz dual-transformer-based power-signal integrated GD for 3.3-kV and 10-kV SiC MOSFETs. To further reduce both the coupling capacitance and footprint of the power-signal integrated GD for MV SiC MOSFETs, a 50-MHz single-transformer-based design is then proposed, and its performance has been experimentally verified by driving 10-kV SiC MOSFET. The PD performance of GD transformer under the high frequency, high dv/dt PWM voltage excitation is also characterized using photo-multiplier tube method.

Due to the lack of comprehensive and quantitative design principles, the conventional DESAT protection circuit parameters usually require trail-and-error efforts to achieve both the sufficient noise immunity to high dv/dt and fast fault response time. To address this issue, the quantitative design constraints and optimization methodology for DESAT circuit parameters are developed with little tuning work. The proposed DESAT circuit parameter design and optimization methodology has been experimentally verified on 3.3-kV SiC MOSFET module.

The conventional DESAT protection scheme cannot be applied into switched-capacitor-based converters due to the inrush current spike occurring at the converter commutation. To eliminate the false-triggering issue induced by the inrush current, a novel charge-based DESAT protection scheme is proposed, where the "fault charge" rather than "fault current" is selected for the fault diagnosis. The proposed charge-based DESAT protection scheme considers the accumulation of fault current over time and thus can screen the narrow inrush current spikes with high magnitude. The proposed charge-based DESAT protection scheme has been designed and experimentally verified on 3.3-kV discrete SiC MOSFETs.

DISS_description.DISS_title: EXPLORATORY FLUX GROWTH AND PROPERTIES OF RARE EARTH SILICIDES AND GALLIDES

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Flux synthesis is a very powerful and versatile technique for the exploratory synthesis of rare earth intermetallics. Reactions of rare earth metals and alkali earth elements with silicon in a Mg/Al flux or a Mg/Zn flux have yielded single crystals of a series of new complex intermetallic phases. The structures of products were determined by single crystal X-ray diffraction. Identical reactions were explored in both fluxes; both yielded large crystals suitable for study using single crystal X-ray diffraction and magnetic susceptibility measurements, although Mg/Zn reactions produced higher yields and larger crystals. While elemental analysis indicates that the product formed in the Mg/Al melts contains traces of aluminum, no incorporation of zinc was observed in compounds formed in the Mg/Zn flux. Reactions of Eu, Ca, and Si in either Mg/Zn or Mg/Al yield products with two structure types depending on the ratio of europium to calcium in the final product. Calcium-rich reactions produce Ca1-xEuxMgSi (0 < x < 0.7) compounds with the orthorhombic TiNiSi structure type in space group Pnma. Increasing europium content led to the prevalence of Eu8-xCaxMg16Si12 (0 < y < 3.4) products with the hexagonal Ho5Ni19P12 structure type in space group P-62m. In all the products, Eu is expected to be divalent, however there may be some switching to a trivalent state in the TiNiSi type compound due to chemical pressure. In all cases these compounds appear to order ferromagnetically. Ba6R1.8Mg18.2Si13 (R = Dy, Y) grow as large crystals from reactions of barium, silicon, and either dysprosium or yttrium in Mg/Al or Mg/Zn fluxes. The presence of the trivalent Y or Dy in the reaction mixture promotes the formation of Ba6R1.8Mg18.2Si13 in the Ho6Ni20P13 structure type (hexagonal P-6 space group) instead of the expected Ba5Mg19Si12 (Ho5Ni19P12 type). The trivalent cations are incorporated at a specific amount in the compound, mixing on one particular Mg site in the structure. Magnetic susceptibility measurements on Ba6Dy1.8Mg18.2Si13 confirm the presence of Dy3+ and indicate magnetic ordering at 9 K. The low melting point of gallium flux enabled an in-situ neutron diffraction study of the reaction of Ce and Ni in excess gallium. Initial formation of CeNi0.74Ga3.26 was seen at high temperature; this transforms into Ce2NiGa10 and Ce2NiGa12 below 600°C. This information enabled isolation of the high temperature phase by quenching the flux reaction at high temperature. CeNi0.74Ga3.26 is a strongly anisotropic ferromagnet below 7 K.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Direct Reactions and Decay Correlations Studying the Proton-Unbound Superradiant State in $^{13}$N

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Angular, Correlations, Direct, Reactions, Structure, Superradiance

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: This work reports on the first efforts at FSU's John D. Fox Accelerator Laboratory to study the nuclear structure of states embedded in the continuum through particle-unbound angular correlations. As part of this work, two principle experiments were performed, both using the $^{12}$C($^{3}$He,$d$)$^{13}$N reaction at $E_{^{3}He}$ = 24 MeV in the Super-Enge Split-Pole Spectrograph (SE-SPS) to populate proton-unbound states in $^{13}$N whose decays were then measured in coincidence by silicon detector arrays. An angular correlation formalism was developed to utilize outputs from the reaction theory code FRESCO between the reaction products (deuterons) and decay products (protons) to connect the decay observables to the fundamental structure of the parent $^{13}$N states. This technique was found to work well for narrow, long-lived states with modest continuum coupling, but to reach its limitations for strongly continuum-coupled states like the broad ``superradiant'' where a more unified description of nuclear structure and reactions is required.

DISS_description.DISS_title: GENERIC DESIRES: GENRE, AGENCY, AND THE POTENTIAL FOR CHANGE IN THE RESEARCH ARTICLE COMPOSING PROCESS OF NEWCOMERS

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: genre, rhetorical genre studies

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Rhetoric and Composition (R/C) practitioners have a variety of ways of enacting the object/motive (Russell, 1997) of the discipline: to study writers and writing. Differing approaches have been well documented in terms of pedagogical styles and their underlying philosophical assumptions (e.g., Berlin, 1982; Faigley, 1986; Berlin, 1988; Kopelson, 2003) or what “counts” as writing in the digital age (Yancey, 2004)—to name a few. Similarly, scholars have pointed out that the whole premise of “writers and writing” has and continues to support white ways of knowing and doing (e.g., Prendergast, 1998; Kynard, 2005; Kynard, 2013). Along with these scholars who contemplate the goals and objects of the discipline, recent Conference of College Composition and Communication calls for presentations (Lindquist, 2019; Hassel, 2020) suggest practitioners take a moment to (re)consider our values. This project offers another approach to answering the question disciplinary values examining how new R/C faculty navigate disciplinary values as they are instantiated in a specific genre, the academic research article (RA).The research article (RA) was chosen because it is an economically central feature of the tenure-track promotion process, as well as a pedagogically central feature of many writing programs’ curricula. Furthermore, the RA is philosophically central as a site where knowledge is authorized, reinforcing what writers and what writing counts as publishable. Finally, the RA is culturally central within the discipline as a socializing feature. Writers who wish to publish RAs—and thus participate with this powerful text in the discipline—must contend with the RA’s generic (genre) norms to produce a text that fits within the discipline’s expectation of what a RA should do. These assertions of how the RA functions in academic spaces echo central tenets of rhetorical genre studies (RGS). RGS, my theoretical framework, acknowledges genres as socialactions (Miller, 1984) that help writers to perform the function of communities, disciplines, or activity systems (Bazerman, 2003) and, as such, are also socializing mechanisms for those communities (Bawarshi, 2003, p. 354). Therefore, writers’ agency is located at the crux of social expectations and personal goals (e.g., Porter, 1986; Russell, 1997; Schryer et al, 2003). RGS also acknowledges that, given these features of genres, individuals are always navigating potentially competing (Russell, 1997) personal and disciplinary motives as they compose what Anis Bawarshi (2000) calls sites for the “articulation…and acquisition of desire” (p. 1-2). This study joins traditional ethnographic methods used in RGS and builds in additional research steps to locate not just texts and their social actions but also locate what might have been left behind, the “rhetorical silences” or strategic omissions (Randazzo, 2015). RGS research methods typically use ethnographic methods for researching in addition to a rhetorical reading of genres (Paré and Smart, 1994). To study genres as sites of desires, I employ a unique methodology in RGS to understand just what sort of desires composers navigate as they engage in the RA-composing process. I surveyed 72 recently graduated R/C faculty, collect documents constituting the “genre set” (Devitt, 1991; Bazerman, 2003) of their RA-composing process, and conduct interviews (Schryer, 2011; Randazzo, 2015) to locate not only what rhetorical moves made it to the final, published products, but also what rhetorical silences, repressions, and/or defenses they may have enacted. Studying “generic desires” helps describe the tensions between individual agency and community norms, but it also requires a different methodological approach to uncover just what desires writers negotiate and how, particularly the “repressions” and “defenses” writers may enact, which may not show up in a final draft (Bawarshi, 2000, p. 98). Bawarshi recognizes that writers exist in and across multiple communities and, similarly, even within a single community may occupy different social positions as writers take up different genres within the community (2000, p. 98). Generic desires are a potent concept for theorizing about genres, agency, and the potential for authors to impact community norms and values. My findings suggest that individuals navigate personal and professional desires along with the desires of the discipline—enacted through the genre and enforced by the journal review process—as they engage in the composing process. These desires shift along the process, demonstrating that articulating and acquiring genres is a mutable, not fixed process. Thus, my findings demonstrate in writers’ own words how generic desire works and where the potential for disciplinary change through “knowledgeable resistance” (Powell, 2003) might exist in the RA-composing process.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Three Essays on Business-State Relations in Authoritarian Regimes

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: This dissertation contains three essays that aim to better understand the topic of business-state relations in authoritarian regimes. To do this, I use various causal inference techniques and utilize Russia as my geographic focus. Below is an overview of each of the three essays.

The first chapter examines whether some judges are more willing to rule in favor of the state than others during business disputes. While previous researchers have studied the court system in authoritarian regimes, very few have examined the factors that shape judges' decision-making, especially in the commercial realm. In this regard, I argue that public sector (e.g., the court bureaucracy, prosecutor's office, investigative services, or other government agencies) judges are more likely to rule in favor of the regime because they may have similar preferences to the autocrat or they may have career incentives because of their lack of employment options outside of the state. To test this hypothesis, I use original data from the Russian commercial courts on the career paths of judges and a sample of more than 200,000 court cases from the last decade. For my causal identification strategy, I exploit the random assignment of cases to judges, ensuring that there are no significant differences in case characteristics that could potentially impact judges’ decisions. Ultimately, I found that public-sector judges are no more likely than private-sector judges to issue favorable rulings toward the state.

The second chapter examines whether corruption scandals impact the value of politically connected firms. While extensive literature examines whether and how political connections affect firm value, no studies have examined whether corruption scandals influence this. To answer this question, I take advantage of the release of a widely viewed Russian documentary film about an alleged corruption scheme involving former Prime Minister Dmitry Medvedev and the anti-corruption protests that followed in March 2017. To estimate the impacts of these events, I use data on political connections to Medvedev and daily stock returns from the Moscow Stock Exchange. For my research design, I use an event study to gauge how investors reacted to these events. In addition, I use synthetic controls to control for any confounding factors. In the end, I found that investors did not respond to either the video or the protests.

Finally, the third chapter explores whether economic sanctions impact the value of firms. While some scholars have examined how sanctions influence macroeconomic outcomes, such as trade or FDI, few have explored firm-level effects. To this end, I contend that investors would respond negatively to economic sanctions because they could cause firms to lose benefits, such as foreign direct investment, access to financing, and various goods and services. To test this hypothesis, I take advantage of the sanctions imposed on multiple Russian businesspeople and their firms for malign activity in April 2018. To estimate the relationship between sanctions and firm value, I utilize data on different firm-level covariates and daily returns from the Moscow Exchange. For my identification strategy, I use an event study to gauge how investors react to the sanctions. In addition, I use synthetic controls to control for any confounding events. Ultimately, I found that investors did not respond to the announcement about the imposition of sanctions against Russian firms or their leadership.

DISS_description.DISS_title: BLACK SCHOLARS MATTER: PSYCHOLOGICAL IMPLICATIONS OF GRADUATE STUDY ON RACIALLY MINORITIZED STUDENTS

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Black Scholars, Historically Black College University, Minority Serving Institutions, Minority Status Stress, Predominately White Institutions, Psychological Distress

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Researchers have reported an overall shortage of Black behavioral health practitioners in the workforce (West & Schoenthaler, 2017). This shortage is problematic because Black and African American people seeking behavioral health services often, at least initially, prefer a same-race practitioner (Swift et al., 2015). Additionally, there is evidence that treatment duration increases (Ratts et al., 2016) and therapeutic outcomes improve (Swift et al., 2015) when there is a racial match between practitioner and client. There are several reasons contributing to this shortage; however, one reason is low retention of racially diverse (e.g. Asian, Black, Latinx) students in graduate training programs (Kaplan et al., 2018; Tinto, 1975; Wu et al., 2020). Major factors involved in retention in graduate school relates to students’ college readiness, sense of belonging within the institution, financial instability, and experiences of racial microaggressions (Joseph, 2012). These factors become more prominent when the students are from racial minority backgrounds, indicating a possible connection to Pillerman’s minority status stress framework (Pillerman, 1988). This framework identifies a unique set of stressors experienced by individuals whom are members of marginalized racial groups; specifically, Black/African American. Additionally, research also indicates that those students experience psychological distress (e.g., anxiety, depression, stress) over and above their White counterparts as a result of their minoritized status. Mitigating or protective factors that are said to reduce development or maintenance of psychological distress can be racial centrality (i.e., race being a significant aspect of identity; Nioplias et al., 2018; Sellers et al., 1997) and attending a historically Black colleges and universities (HBCUs) (Joseph, 2012). Therefore, the purpose of this study was to examine associations between minority status stress and psychological distress (i.e., anxiety, depression, and stress) among Black students enrolled in behavioral health training graduate programs. Implications from this study will aid administrators and policy makers, at PWIs, in creating a safe and supportive environment for their students of color, which can ultimately impact these students’ persistence and degree completion. The results of the present study demonstrated a significant relationship between MSS and psychological distress (Research Question 1), along with the inclusion of racial centrality held constant (Research Question 2). However, the inclusion of school type (PWI, MSI, HBCU) had no effect on the degree to which MSS and psychological distress were correlated (Research Question 3). Keywords: minority status stress, psychological distress, HBCU, PWI

DISS_description.DISS_title: EXPLORING MOBILE PERFORMANCE SUPPORT SYSTEMS IN THE WORKFORCE

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Mobile Technology, Performance Support, Workforce development

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Mobile performance support systems (MPSS) are being adopted to support workforce performance across many industries and organizations. An MPSS provides just-in-time access to assist workers with their job tasks from anywhere with minimal help from others (Gery, 1995b; Hueftle, 2005; Layton et al., 1995; Ruffner & Deibler, 2010). A review of the literature suggests that empirical research on MPSS is sparse and sporadic. Scholars from human performance technology (HPT), computer science, engineering, and business fields have called for additional studies on MPSS (Egger & Masood, 2020; Porcelli et al., 2013; Rossett, 2011). To date, only a few studies have explored the use of MPSS in the context of HPT. The purpose of this study was to explore why MPSS is adopted in companies and organizations in North America to solve performance problems and meet organizational goals. The study focused on why MPSS is considered an appropriate intervention, the benefits of adopting MPSS, and the challenges in the adoption. The three research questions of the study are: I. Why is MPSS adopted in the workplace? II. What are the benefits of adopting MPSS in the workplace? III. What are the challenges that participants encountered in MPSS adoption? To answer these questions, the study employed qualitative field interviews. Managers and leaders of MPSS projects from 13 companies and organizations in North America joined the study, representing government, military, transportation, aviation, health care, higher education, medical, restaurant, retailing, semiconductors, and manufacturing. The results led to the identification of ten main reasons, six salient benefits, and 12 top challenges reported by over 30% of participants. The main reasons for adopting MPSS were to improve efficiency, aid work in the field, lower costs, provide support in the moment, minimize human errors, manage content, meet job condition requirements, alleviate worker burdens, assist highly complex tasks, and support learning. The salient benefits for adopting MPSS were to boost performance, build confidence, encourage professional satisfaction, increase ROI, manage corporate knowledge, and enhance organizational reputation. The 12 prevailing challenges in MPSS adoption were grouped into four themes: change management (resistance, organizational culture, project planning, change implementation), technology usability consideration (Wi-Fi connection, interface design, device and infrastructure, environment), intervention design and development (development and delivery, content creation and maintenance), and project-related issues (cost and return, IT support). The findings of the study provide insight about the adoption of MPSS in the workplace. As the use of mobile technologies continue to expand and penetrate our daily lives, the results can help HPT professionals strategically adopt MPSS to support performance instead of blindly following current trends.

DISS_description.DISS_title: AN ONLINE SCAFFOLDED WRITING TIME MANAGEMENT INTERVENTION TO REDUCE WRITING ANXIETY AND INCREASE WRITING PERFORMANCE IN UNDERGRADUATE STUDENTS: A REPEATED MEASURES RANDOM CONTROL TRIAL

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Intervention, Random Control Trial, Self-Efficacy for Writing Self-Regulation, Writing Anxiety, Writing Performance, Writing Self-Efficacy

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Many students experience writing anxiety, which may lead to students dropping out of or changing classes, majors, college, or professions to get away from writing requirements. This repeated measures random control trial tested the effect of an online scaffolded writing time management intervention on two outcome variables (1) writing performance and (2) writing anxiety. The intervention was designed to help students reduce their writing anxiety by providing structure and guidance to help students self-regulate (keep themselves on task during the pursuit of a goal; Zimmerman, 2000) in the context of a writing assignment. This study also explored the impact of five moderator variables: (1) writing self-efficacy, (2) self-efficacy for writing self-regulation, (3) procrastination, (4) gender, and (5) year-in-school. Participants of the study were 118 undergraduate students from fall and spring Educational Psychology courses. Participants were randomly assigned to either the control (business-as-usual) or intervention condition. Participants received pre-test measures at time 1 when the assignment was introduced, a writing anxiety and writing self-efficacy measure at time 2 during the week the assignment was due, and post-test measures at time 3 after students submitted their assignment but before receiving their grades. Only writing anxiety and writing self-efficacy were measured at all three time points. The main analysis of the effect of the intervention on writing performance was severely underpowered; however, the moderator analyses had some significant and adequately powered results. Student writing self-efficacy moderated the effect of the intervention on writing performance (? = .045). Specifically, participants in the intervention with below average writing self-efficacy at T1 had a significantly higher score (23.6%) on writing performance (? = .033, ? = -1.900). While the overall test of students’ self-efficacy for writing self-regulation did not moderate the effect of the intervention on writing performance (? = .203), it was underpowered and visually presented an interaction. Follow up tests revealed, that participants in the intervention with above average self-efficacy for writing self-regulation had a significantly higher grade (22.1%) on writing performance (? < .001, ? = -2.186), leading to the overall conclusion that a student’s perceived self-efficacy for writing self-regulation does moderate the effect on writing performance. Results indicated that there was an increase in writing anxiety scores between T1 and T2 for all participants (? = .024) and specifically for the control group between T1 and T2 (? = .048), however, when corrected for Type I error these tests were not significant. The intervention also may have stabilized participants‘ writing anxiety. There were two moderators from the writing anxiety tests with enough power to form a conclusion. Both procrastination (? = .515, ηp² =.305) and self-efficacy for writing self-regulation (? = .269, ηp² =.304) did not moderate the effect of the intervention on writing anxiety. All other analyses were underpowered. Implications and directions for future research are discussed.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Dimensions of internalizing and externalizing psychopathology and suicidal ideation and attempts in a sample of ethnoracially diverse youth

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: dimensional psychopathology, externalizing psychopathology, internalizing psychopathology, structural invariance, suicide

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Suicide is a leading cause of death and a serious public health problem in the U.S., with certain age, gender, and ethnoracial subgroups being at greater risk. Incorporating dimensional models of psychopathology (e.g., Hierarchical Taxonomy of Psychopathology) into suicide prediction models may improve performance and effectiveness of the prediction of suicidal thoughts and behaviors (STBs). Such efforts may be complemented by examining whether dimensional psychopathology and STB prediction models are valid and applicable across diverse identities, as samples in both dimensional psychopathology and STB literature tend to lack diversity. Thus, multi-group confirmatory factor analyses were conducted to assess structural invariance of the dimensional psychopathology model across sex assigned at birth and ethnoracial identity in a sample of substance-using young adults (n = 511). Additionally, hierarchical logistic regression analyses were conducted to examine the associations between the dimensional internalizing and externalizing psychopathology factors and suicidal ideation (SI) and suicide attempts (SA) and whether these associations were moderated by sex assigned at birth and ethnoracial identity moderated the association between. Structural invariance testing results supported partial metric (i.e., weak) invariance of the dimensional internalizing and externalizing psychopathology model across sex assigned at birth and ethnoracial identity. Logistic regression models indicated internalizing psychopathology was significantly correlated with suicidal ideation (SI) and suicide attempts (SA) above externalizing psychopathology; follow-up mediation analyses showed the association between externalizing and SI and SA was fully mediated by internalizing. No significant moderation effects were found for ethnoracial status, indicating the association between internalizing and externalizing psychopathology and SI and SA did not differ across ethnoracial identity. Moderation results showed the association between internalizing and SI were stronger at higher levels of externalizing for females and lower levels of externalizing for males.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Generating and Evaluating Camouflage Patterns for Littoral Environments of Northwest Florida

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Camouflage Assessment, Camouflage Patterns, Color Extraction, Generative Models, Littoral Environment, Machine Learning

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Historically, soldiers wore decorative uniforms to distinguish between friend and foe on the battlefield. During World War I, heavy casualties caused the French Army to recruit artists to develop camouflage patterns for their battlefield uniforms. Since then, military camouflage uniforms have been universally implemented for forest, desert, grassland, ocean, and snowy environments. Although many nations have international boundaries that border a large body of water, very limited research has been conducted to develop camouflage patterns for littoral environments. Currently, camouflage pattern effectiveness are evaluated by using the camouflage similarity index (CSI). This technique, however, has drawbacks due to the heterogeneity of camouflage designs and the under-representation of environmental features. Hence, the two overall goals for this research are to (i) create novel littoral camouflage patterns for Northwest Florida’s coastal environments, and to (ii) develop new camouflage assessment procedures.

In the first goal, new littoral camouflage patterns were modeled after eight variations of military camouflage designs. These patterns were created by inserting dominant environmental colors for Northwest Florida’s littoral environments into eight custom-built digital camouflage templates. The dominant colors were extracted from three custom-built images datasets for Northwest Florida’s estuarine, sandy, and combination estuarine-sandy coastlines. Twenty-four new littoral camouflage patterns were created by using these custom-made templates. These camouflage patterns were then used to produce the 64x64-pixel camouflage swatches, the 128x128-pixel camouflage patterns, and the 256x256-pixel camouflage patterns training datasets. Each training dataset had three variations for Northwest Florida’s three types of shorelines. As a result, nine custom-made training datasets were produced to train generative models to output novel littoral camouflage patterns. These generative models included a variational autoencoder (VAE), a generative adversarial network (GAN), and a deep convolutional generative adversarial network (DCGAN).

The second research goal was to develop new camouflage pattern evaluation procedures. A novel camouflage assessment method (NCAM) was created. It overcame the CSI drawbacks by achieving a better representation of a camouflage design and a natural environment. The NCAMs for each novel camouflage pattern were sorted in ascending order. The most effective pattern had the lowest NCAM and a ranking of one. The least effective pattern had a NCAM of one and a ranking of 81. A new camouflage pattern rating system that uses a holistic approach for assessing camouflage patterns was then developed. It was based on NCAMs, runtimes, absence or presence of unusual features, and design appearances. This rating system could be adapted to incorporate other camouflage assessment methods to rank patterns. It has seven categories ranging from “best” to “worst”. Each novel camouflage pattern was assessed by using this rating system.

The impact of hyperparameters on pattern effectiveness was analyzed. The overall effectiveness of camouflage patterns, generative models, the impact of training dataset pixel size on pattern ratings, and the effect of training epochs on pattern appearances were also addressed.

There were eight contributions for this investigation, and they were grouped into five categories. The first area was to develop a glossary of littoral terms that provided definitions and locations of Northwest Florida coastal features. It could be used for educational purposes and for other types of littoral research to include beach re-nourishment, wildlife biology, and ecological research. The second involved developing two types of custom-built datasets because they are unavailable in the public domain. The littoral images and camouflage training datasets were required for creating and evaluating new camouflage patterns. The third contribution involved creating digital camouflage templates to facilitate creating new patterns. These templates are also not available in the public domain. The fourth involved creating new littoral camouflage patterns by using two different procedures. The first was to insert extracted colors from the littoral images datasets into the digital templates. The second was to create novel camouflage patterns by training generative models on the custom-built camouflage training datasets. Currently, littoral camouflage patterns are unavailable for use by militaries. The fifth contribution area involved developing two camouflage pattern evaluation procedures: NCAM and camouflage pattern rating system. The NCAM overcomes CSI drawbacks to achieve a better representation of a camouflage pattern and an environment. The camouflage pattern rating system is a holistic approach developed to evaluate camouflage pattern effectiveness. It takes into account NCAMs, runtimes, design artifacts, and design appearances. This rating system could be adapted to incorporate other camouflage assessment methods, such as the combined NCAM-SSIM procedure.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Fusion of East and West in Selected Piano Works by Contemporary Chinese Composers

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: This treatise is a study of selected contemporary solo piano works by prominent Chinese composers. The focus is on demonstrating how each composer engages both Eastern and Western elements in their piano music creating their own distinctive compositional styles.

The piano works discussed are Bamboo Song (2013) by Chen Yi, Pianobells (2012) by Zhou Long, Namucuo, Op. 53 (2006) by Xiaogang Ye, and Three Preludes, Op. 18 (1998) by Shuai Zhang. After a brief introduction to the development of piano music in China, there are four chapters that include a biographical sketch of each composer followed by an analytical discussion of each piece.

DISS_description.DISS_title: THE EVOLVING LANDSCAPE OF LGBTQ+ SUPPORT IN HIGHER EDUCATION: A QUALITATIVE STUDY OF INITIATIVES AND LEADERSHIP PRACTICES IN LARGE PUBLIC UNIVERSITIES

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: This study offers an overview of the landscape of LGBTQ+ leadership and initiatives at large public universities in the state of Florida. Through the recognition that LGBTQ+ leaders often have to navigate complex institutional, social, and political systems, Bronfenbrenner’s Ecological Systems Theory provided the theoretical framework for the study and served as a way to examine the relationships between the leaders and the varying institutional bodies they serve. Eight leaders from seven of Florida’s public universities were interviewed in this qualitative, exploratory study, and the study was guided by questions related to how leaders were supporting their LGBTQ+ populations and how LGBTQ+ initiatives were being designed to engage with students in virtual environments. The findings suggest that leaders support LGBTQ+ populations in three ways: through advocacy work, educational training and programming, and community building. Regarding how LGBTQ+ initiatives are being designed for virtual environments, the findings reveal that leaders develop strategic communications plans, leverage social media, and design and develop their programming for hybrid and online delivery. Because the findings highlight the value of partnerships as ways to advance diversity, equity, and inclusion work, the implications are presented for LGBTQ+ leaders, LGBTQ+ leaders and faculty, and LGBTQ+ leaders and instructional designers.

DISS_description.DISS_title: TRANSGENERATIONAL TRANSMISSION OF CHANGES IN BEHAVIOR, NEUROTRANSMITTER SIGNALING, AND GENE EXPRESSION IN THE AMYGDALA FOLLOWING ASPARTAME CONSUMPTION

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: I report the effects of aspartame on anxiety-like behavior, neurotransmitter signaling and gene expression in the amygdala, a brain region associated with the regulation of anxiety and fear responses. C57BL/6 mice consumed drinking water containing 0.015% or 0.03% aspartame, a dose equivalent of 8-15% of the FDA recommended maximum human daily intake, or plain drinking water. Robust anxiety-like behavior (evaluated using open field test and elevated zero maze) was observed in male and female mice consuming the aspartame-containing water. Diazepam, an allosteric modulator of the GABA-A receptor, alleviated the anxiety. RNA sequencing of the amygdala followed by KEGG biological pathway analysis of differentially expressed genes showed glutamatergic and GABAergic synapse pathways as significantly enriched. Quantitative PCR showed upregulation of mRNA for the glutamate NMDA receptor subunit 2D (Grin2d) and metabotropic receptor 4 (Grm4), and downregulation of the GABA-A receptor associated protein (Gabarap) mRNA. Thus, taken together, our diazepam and gene expression data show that aspartame consumption shifted the excitation-inhibition equilibrium in the amygdala toward excitation. Even more strikingly, the anxiety-like behavior, its response to diazepam, and changes in amygdala gene expression were transmitted to male and female offspring in two generations descending from the aspartame-exposed males. Extrapolation of the findings to humans suggests that aspartame consumption at doses below the FDA recommended maximum daily intake may produce neurobehavioral changes in aspartame-consuming individuals and their descendants. Thus, human population at risk of aspartame’s potential mental health effects may be larger than current expectations, which only include aspartame consuming individuals.

DISS_description.DISS_title: REWARD SENSITIVITY AND ITS RELATIONSHIP TO INITIATION OF ALCOHOL USE AND PAST MONTH CONSUMPTION IN FEMALE ADOLESCENTS

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Alcohol, ERP, Reward, RewP, Youth

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Adolescence is a period of increased risk-taking behaviors including the initiation of alcohol use, which appears mechanistically related to the brain’s reward system. Available evidence provides support for both hyposensitivity and hypersensitivity as mediators of substance or alcohol use escalation – calling for further research to better understand the role of reward systems in risk trajectories, utilizing effective indices of reward processing. The reward positivity (RewP) is a commonly utilized index of hedonic “liking,” an important aspect of reward activation. Existing studies with adults have provided evidence for reduced, enhanced, or intact RewP among samples with risk for, or histories of problem drinking or other harmful substance use. However, to date, no research has examined relations between youth alcohol use and RewP, although research on adolescents at risk for substance use, or currently using tobacco or cannabis, has not found differences in RewP relative to adolescent controls, outside of one past sex-specific finding in adolescent males. The current study measured the RewP within a binary-choice reward task in a large sample (N = 250) of adolescent females (Mage = 14.40) to evaluate its predictive association with self-reported drinking initiation and past-month drinking. Regression analyses showed that adolescents who had initiated drinking exhibited a smaller RewP—specifically, a smaller response to monetary gain feedback—compared to not-yet drinkers. There was no difference in RewP between past-month drinkers and non-drinkers. These findings provide evidence for the importance of limited capacity for hedonic “liking” as a risk factor for early initiation of drinking in adolescent females, while other patterns may underlie likelihood for proximal drinking escalation. Future studies should incorporate additional indices of reward activation, and mixed-sex samples with greater drinking variability to replicate current study findings and test for sex moderation of observed reward-response/drinking associations.

DISS_description.DISS_title: RESURRECTION OF ANCESTRAL GLUCOKINASES TO STUDY THE ORIGINS OF A NEW REGULATORY MECHANISM

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Allosteric regulation, Ancestral protein reconstruction, Enzyme cooperativity, Glucokinase, Protein function regulation, Structural dynamics

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Protein function needs to get regulated in every organism, and mis-regulation of protein function can cause serious disease states. Regulation of protein function is essential for controlling and organizing many different cellular processes. It has been postulated that the emergence of a new regulatory mechanism often requires protein conformational heterogeneity. In another word, protein needs to have access to two or more different conformations. Although there are many studies performed on different polypeptides and the regulatory processes associated with them, there is little knowledge available regarding the evolutionary origins of new regulatory mechanisms. One example of such regulatory process is allosteric regulation. One example of allosteric regulation is the allosteric regulation of glucokinase by one of its substrate glucose. Glucokinase is the primary glucose sensor in human body and a key determinant of glucose homeostasis in vertebrates. Allosteric regulation of glucokinase is of substantial interest as glucokinase is a monomeric enzyme and has just one binding site for glucose. Mis-regulation of glucokinase activity causes diabetes and hyperinsulinemia. Glucokinase is an ideal system to investigate the evolutionary link between conformational heterogeneity and regulation because: glucokinase is regulated by several mechanisms that require access to multiple states, also, glucokinase is evolutionarily tractable. As such, understanding the evolutionary origins of glucokinase regulatory processes provides direct insight into the emergence of physiology and disease. The aim of this research is to understand how evolution, by the means of natural selection, altered protein sequence, structure and function to introduce a new regulatory mechanism. For this purpose, herein, I reconstructed ancestral glucokinase sequences, resurrected extinct proteins and performed biophysical analyses to illuminate the functional transitions that afford access to new glucokinase conformations. I used a variety of techniques such as kinetic assays, proteolysis, X-ray crystallography and nuclear magnetic resonance experiments for the purpose of this study.

DISS_description.DISS_title: THE “INFLUENTIAL RELATIONSHIP”: UNDERSTANDING SOURCE FACTORS AMONG SOCIAL MEDIA FASHION INFLUENCERS AND IMPACTS ON CONSUMERS’ ATTITUDES AND BEHAVIORAL INTENTIONS

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Attitude, Influencer Marketing, Purchase Intention, Social Media Fashion Influencer, Social Media Influencer

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: The growth of social media has created a new type of celebrity, referred to as social media influencers (SMI) (Appel, Grewal, Hadi, Stephen, 2020), and a new endorsement technique known as influencer marketing (Brown, Hayes, 2008). Influencer marketing is particularly dominant in the beauty and fashion industries (Driver, 2018).Despite the growth in the influencer marketing industry, the amount of academic research on social media influencers is insufficient (Taillon, Mueller, Kowalczyk, Jones, 2020). In addition, there are inconsistencies across the literature about the source factors’ outcomes. Finally, a significant majority of the research in the area of SMI, examined the effectiveness of SMIs in a broad context and not in a specific product category. The main objective of this dissertation is to investigate the influence of source factors among social media fashion influencers (SMFIs), including perceived trustworthiness, expertise, physical attractiveness, perceived similarity, likability, and identification, on consumers’ attitudes toward SMFIs and consumers’ attitudes toward the product endorsed by SMFIs. Next, the impacts of consumers’ attitudes toward SMFIs, and attitudes toward the endorsed product, on consumers’ purchase intentions are explored.
